keyInsights.title: Current Cyber Risk Exposure<Asterisk>*</Asterisk> - Key Insights

aal.title: Average Annual Loss
aal.description: Risk combines the likelihood of unwanted events with their financial impact. The Average Annual Loss (AAL) reflects this by averaging the total financial losses from all simulated attacks, accounting for both high and low-loss attacks and their probabilities. In CRQ AAL is a key metric for assessing and comparing a company’s risk over time or against remediation plans.

highExposureLoss.title: 1:100 Annual Loss <RegularText>(<1% Probability)</RegularText>
highExposureLoss.description: The 1:100 Annual Loss reflects a 1% chance of a loss occurring or being exceeded in the next year, showing maximum probable risk (rare, but still possible, and highly impactful). Along with AAL, it provides a full view of risk exposure, helping companies evaluate and track remediation efforts.

remediationPlans.title: Remediation Plans
remediationPlans.description: This report shows how Microsoft Defender CSPM reduces financial risk by lowering both the Average Annual Loss and 1:100 Annual Loss, comparing current risk with a profile that includes this product. Details on the simulation and results are on <AnchorLink target='chapter2'>Chapter 2</AnchorLink>.

cyberRiskExposureAsterisk.text: Cyber Risk Quantification (CRQ) estimates the potential financial impact of cyber incidents on your organization by leveraging vast amounts of data and extensive simulations. Powered by millions of continuously updated data points (see details on <PageLink target='{{pageId}}'>p.</PageLink>), Kovrr's risk model simulates all the attacks your company might experience in the next year. These simulations are run thousands of times to derive conclusions from the results, providing meaningful insights into your cyber risk exposure.

crqProcess.title: How are these results generated - The CRQ Process

baselineAnnualLikelihood.title: Baseline Annual Likelihood of Cyber Loss Events
baselineAnnualLikelihood.description: This figure shows the baseline likelihood of a cyber loss in the next year, reflecting the company’s risk profile based on historical data, insurance claims, and modeling insights. More details on datasets and calibration are on <PageLink target='{{pageId1}}'>p.</PageLink> and <PageLink target='{{pageId2}}'>p.</PageLink>.

bespokeEventCatalog.title: Bespoke Event Catalog and Monte Carlo Simulation
bespokeEventCatalog.description: The next year is simulated 10,000 times using a custom event catalog that generates synthetic cyber incidents based on various parameters and their likelihood of affecting the company. Each event represents a potential cyber threat.

rows: Randomly sampled from distributions based on threat intelligence data (You can have a glimpse of this TI data on <PageLink target='eventTypeFindings'>p.</PageLink>), adjusted for the company's security posture (You can see these adjustments on <PageLink target='likelihoodBreakdown'>p.</PageLink>).
rowsContinued: Randomly sampled from distributions based on threat intelligence data (You can have a glimpse of this TI data on <PageLink target='attackVectorsDistribution'>p.</PageLink>), adjusted for the company's security posture (You can see these adjustments on <PageLink target='annualLikelihoodBreakdown'>p.</PageLink>).
Technologies & Service Providers impacted by the event.

Randomly sampled based on threat, vulnerabilities (CVEs, EPSS), and outage data insights (You can have a glimpse of this TI data on <PageLink target='exploitedCves'>p.</PageLink> and <PageLink target='globalDowntime'>p.</PageLink>)
The length of time the event impacts the organization.
Randomly sampled from threat intelligence data distributions, adjusted by the company’s recovery abilities and resilience (reflected on <PageLink target='dataManagement'>p.</PageLink>).
The magnitude of the breach in terms of the number of records affected.
Randomly sampled from impact distributions based on threat intelligence from similar company breaches.

residualAnnualLikelihood.title: Specific (Residual) Annual Likelihood of Cyber Loss Events
residualAnnualLikelihood.description: The baseline likelihood is refined by incorporating specific data from integrations, internal sources, and a security controls questionnaire. The primary driver of the shift from baseline to final risk is the company's security posture. Learn more on <PageLink target='{{pageId1}}'>p.</PageLink> and <PageLink target='{{pageId2}}'>p.</PageLink>.

damageCalculation.title: Damage Calculation
damageCalculation.description: For each sampled event, costs are broken down by damage type. calculated using historical data and modeling insights. Specific security controls are demonstrated to mitigate these costs, reducing the event’s overall impact.

annualPerspective.title: Annual Perspective
annualPerspective.description: After calculating each event’s financial impact, the total cost is determined for each simulation run. Most show minimal or no loss, while a few have significant losses. By plotting loss amounts against their probability, the <AnchorLink target='epCurve'>the EP curve</AnchorLink> is generated, visualizing the likelihood of different loss levels. The Average Annual Loss is the sum of total losses divided by the number of simulations, and the 1:100 Annual Loss is the 99th percentile value. Learn more about the full view of risk of the company on <PageLink target='{{pageId}}'>p.</PageLink>.

whatIfScenarios.title: What-If Scenarios: Remediation Plans
whatIfScenarios.description: To test a remediation plan, the simulation is rerun with the same inputs, adjusting only the security posture. This shows how the plan impacts risk, allowing comparison with the baseline to assess its effect on reducing event likelihood and severity.

currentCyberRiskExposure.title: Current Cyber Risk Exposure
chapterIntro: Understanding the quantifiable aspects of cyber risk exposure has become paramount for organizations seeking to fortify their security strategies.

The Cyber Risk Quantification (CRQ) methodology offers a unique, data-driven approach to assess, measure, and manage cyber risks effectively. By translating complex cyber threats into tangible financial metrics, CRQ empowers businesses to make informed decisions, allocate resources more efficiently, and tailor their cyber risk management efforts to their specific needs. This innovative methodology shifts cybersecurity discussions from vague hypotheticals to concrete figures, enabling organizations to communicate risk more effectively, prioritize mitigation efforts, and strengthen their company's cyber resilience in an increasingly complex threat landscape.

This chapter presents the key insights into your company's quantitative cyber risk exposure. By harnessing precise data, insightful modeling, and rigorous analysis, this analysis  illuminates the financial implications of cyber risks and paves the way for informed decision-making when evaluating your cybersecurity programs' return on investment.

aal.title: Average Annual Loss
aal.description: The "average annual loss" offers a clear picture of the typical monetary impact of cyber events, aiding organizations in gauging potential financial ramifications. This metric encapsulates both probability and severity of the cyber risk for the company. It is an essential reference point for devising effective risk management tactics as it serves as a benchmark against which various strategies can be evaluated and refined.

extremeLoss.title: 1:100 Annual Loss
extremeLoss.description: The "1:100 Annual Loss" represents the loss amount the company has a mere 1% probability of surpassing within an annual context. This value encapsulates "tail events", or those exceptional situations at the outermost edge of your company's overall cyber risk exposure spectrum.

financialLossCurve.title: Financial Loss Exceedance Probability Curve
description: The exceedance probability curve below represents the relationship between the probability of experiencing a certain level of loss and the corresponding financial severity within a yearly context. The probability curve is based on the Monte Carlo simulation, generating 10,000 possible cyber risk scenarios for the upcoming year.

The curve provides valuable insights into your organization's potential financial losses due to specific cyber events, aiding in your team in setting appropriate risk tolerance levels. Moreover, the organization can more easily prioritize risk mitigation efforts, focusing on those risks which pose the highest loss potential, and determine appropriate insurance coverage levels. Finally, the curve also highlights critical loss thresholds or “tail events” with a low but non-zero probability occurring, allowing your organization to better understanding its overall threat landscape.

annualEventLikelihood.title: Annual Events Likelihood
description: The ”annual events likelihood” rate refers to the probability of cyber events occurring in the company within the following year.

This rate encompasses the frequency at which cyber events are expected to happen based on the risks in the threat landscape, and accounts for the company’s attributes, structure, and security posture.

aalBreakdownByEventType.title: Average Annual Loss Breakdown by Event Types
description: A breakdown of the average annual loss by event type offers a detailed understanding of the financial impact from different cyber events.
By categorizing events into these high-level threat types, organizations can understand their risk better and prioritize risk mitigation efforts accordingly.

data_breach.title: Data Breach
definitions: Events involving unauthorized access, acquisition, and potential disclosure of sensitive information, including regulated personal records (PII), health (PHI), or financial information (PCI).

Other confidential information can also be included such as intellectual property (IP) in this category using custom cost components. The primary impact of these events is a confidentiality compromise, leading to costs of notifications, monitoring services, regulatory, recovery expenses and more. Data breach events can impact availability by necessitating immediate actions such as system shutdowns or assessments of exposure extent.

interruption.title: Interruption
definitions: Events that cause disruptions or impairments to target systems resulting in a loss of availability or denial of service (DoS).

These events arise from various malicious causes such as attacks, hardware or software failures induced by attackers, or network outages orchestrated by malicious actors. Their objective is to disrupt critical systems, services, or resources, leading to downtime and impeding regular business operations.

ransomware.title: Ransomware
definitions: Events where there is a financial incentive targeted by the attacker in the form of an extortion payment.

This may take the form malicious software which encrypts critical data, blocking or disrupting access to computers systems and databases, or the threat of the public release of data, unless an amount is paid to the attacker. These incidents can significantly impact businesses in terms of their availability, confidentiality and integrity.

attritional.title: Attritional
definitions: Under attritional, we model expected, recurring, or ongoing losses a company may face due to expected and frequent cyber incidents.
These losses can derive from unsuccessful phishing attempts, low-profile data breaches with limited data exposure, or minor cybersecurity incidents that are quickly addressed.

InitialVectorAalBreakdown.title: Average Annual Loss Breakdown by Initial Vectors
InitialVectorAalBreakdown.description: This breakdown of initial access vectors helps you understand the specific methods (as defined by MITRE ATT&CK framework) threat actors employ and routes they are most likely to take to gain unauthorized access into your company and their associated financial implications.

mostLikelyLoss.title: Most Likely Loss From an Event
mostLikelyLoss.description: The expected loss from a cyber event occurring to the company will likely be within this range (between the 40th and 60th percentiles).

extremeLoss.title: Loss From Severe Event
extremeLoss.description: The expected loss from a severe cyber event occurring to the company will likely be within this range (between the 95th and 99th percentiles).

lossEvents.bottom: Loss events from the past 8 years

findings: Modeling the impacts of cyber events necessitates a deep understanding of the cyber threat landscape.
At the core of Kovrr's data pipeline lies a fusion of unique data sources, enhancing the insights used to construct the frequency and severity of cyber events in our models.

Kovrr's data collection technology aggregates data from numerous sources into Kovrr’s threat intelligence and cyber events databases. Access to certain data sources is facilitated through exclusive partnerships reserved for Kovrr, enhancing our modeling capabilities.

dataSources.intro: Kovrr's data sources can be categorized into four main groups:
sources: <Bold>Cyber Events Data:</Bold> This encompasses data related to cyber events, including event types, attack vectors, event durations, impacts, and associated costs.

<Bold>Threat Landscape and Intelligence Data:</Bold> This includes information on actor activities and compromised resources. Examples include compromised personally identifiable information (PII), credentials, and trends in actor activities.

<Bold>Vulnerability and Exploits Data:</Bold> This data category covers vulnerable and exploited products, types of vulnerabilities and exploits, and trends in vulnerabilities and exploits (e.g., actively exploited vulnerabilities).
<Bold>Outage Data:</Bold> This data pertains to service provider outages, providing insights into which providers are more susceptible to outages and the average duration of such outages.

msBundles.title: Return on Cyber Risk Investment Assessment: <RegularText>Microsoft Security Products Bundles</RegularText>
msBundles.description: In the previous chapter, we outlined the company's current cyber risk profile based on its existing cybersecurity measures. To assess how the implementation of Microsoft Security Products Bundles would impact this risk, we conducted a new quantification, altering only one variable: the addition of a bundle. This allowed us to simulate the company's cyber risk landscape as if the product had been fully integrated into their operations. The analysis you will see in this chapter reflects the outcome of these adjustment, offering a comparative view of risk reduction.

cspm.title: Return on Cyber Risk Investment Assessment: <RegularText>Microsoft Defender CSPM</RegularText>
description: In the previous chapter, we outlined the company's current cyber risk profile based on its existing cybersecurity measures. To assess how the implementation of Microsoft Defender CSPM would impact this risk, we conducted a new quantification, altering only one variable: the addition of the product. This allowed us to simulate the company's cyber risk landscape as if the product had been fully integrated into their cloud operations. The analysis you will see in this chapter reflects the outcome of these adjustment, offering a comparative view of risk reduction.

When conducting the "What If" scenario quantification, we specifically applied the improvements to the CIS Controls related only to the cloud environment. This approach aligns with the fact that Microsoft Defender CSPM is a cloud-focused security product. By limiting the enhancements to cloud-related controls, we can more accurately assess the product's impact on the organization's cloud security posture, ensuring that the results of the quantification are relevant and reflective of the product's intended use case.
cspm.productIntro: Microsoft Defender CSPM (Cloud Security Posture Management) is a comprehensive solution designed to enhance cloud security by continuously monitoring and managing your cloud environment's security posture. It offers advanced tools for identifying, assessing, and remediating vulnerabilities across multi-cloud environments, helping organizations proactively mitigate risks. By integrating automated compliance checks, threat detection, and real-time insights, Microsoft Defender CSPM provides a streamlined approach to securing cloud infrastructure and ensuring consistent adherence to security best practices.

coreCapabilities.title: Core Capabilities
coreCapabilities.description: The table below summarizes the core capabilities of the Microsoft Defender CSPM, which helps organizations secure their cloud environments effectively.

rows: Provides ongoing evaluation of cloud environments against security benchmarks and industry standards, identifying potential risks and vulnerabilities.
Tracks and reports compliance status with regulatory standards, enabling users to ensure adherence to policies like CIS, NIST, and GDPR.
Offers a visual representation of potential attack paths within the cloud environment, helping to prioritize the most critical vulnerabilities for remediation.
Assigns a score to the cloud environment based on security configuration, allowing users to benchmark and track improvements over time.
Suggests and simplifies remediation via a fix button to quickly remediate recommendations for identified security issues, reducing manual effort and response times.
Seamlessly integrates with Microsoft Defender XDR to provide a unified security front by accessing alerts and getting a complete picture of an attack in the Microsoft Defender Portal
Provides a centralized view of all cloud resources, helping users to understand their environment and detect unprotected or misconfigured assets.
Delivers actionable security recommendations tailored to the specific cloud setup, helping to improve overall security posture and reduce risk exposure.
Allows users to create, assign, and enforce security policies across their cloud environments, ensuring consistency in security practices.
Offers interactive dashboards for monitoring compliance status, helping organizations to quickly identify gaps and take corrective actions to achieve compliance.

<Bold>4.4</Bold>: Implement and Manage a Firewall on Servers.

inDepthExamination.title: In-Depth Quantification Examination
description: The Cyber Risk Quantification process involves leveraging various data sources, statistical models, and analytical techniques to simulate and predict the likelihood and severity of cyber events and their potential financial consequences.
This chapter offers an in-depth exploration of the distinct phases we undertake to quantify the organization's cyber risk exposure.

threatIntelligence.title: Threat Intelligence
description: Our first step is understanding your company's basic risk level. We do this by studying trends in the threat landscape among companies that share similar characteristics to yours. By looking at how similar companies have been affected by cyber threats, we can better gauge the potential risks your organization faces.

By analyzing firmographics such as industry, company size, location, and revenue, we discern a comprehensive understanding of the company's operational landscape and potential outcomes of a cyber event.

This data, gathered from both privileged and public sources, allows us to identify common cyber threats and prevalent attack vectors among peers and establish a foundational knowledge of the company's exposure to cyber risks.

peerBaseRate.title: Peer Base Rate
peerBaseRate.description: The graph below shows what is the baseline annual likelihood, also referred to as the 'Peer Base Rate' compared to your company’s residual annual likelihood to experience a cyber loss event.

breakdownByEventType.title: Breakdown by Event Type
description: The peer base rate is determined by summing the base rates for three types of events: Data Breach, Interruption, and Ransomware.
The graph below shows what is the baseline likelihood for the three types of events, compared to your company’s likelihood residual rates.

findingsExplanation.description1: To form the base probabilities, Kovrr meticulously examines various datasets using Bayesian methods. This approach accounts for reporting delays, data gaps, and uncertainties to ensure robust analysis.
findingsExplanation.boldDescription: Calibration Factors Applied to Raw Data
description2: The first calibration factor involves analyzing historical data to identify trends. For instance, if the incident rate in a particular industry remained stable for several years and then gradually increased, our model captures this trend. By considering historical patterns, the model enhances its predictive capabilities, allowing us to factor in evolving risks and better prepare for future scenarios.

The first “uplift” relates to events that experience reporting delays. These events eventually get reported, but there is a time gap between their occurrence and official documentation. During this gap, the model considers them as "unreported," leading to a higher likelihood rate. Once the reports are filed, the model is adjusted accordingly.

Some events may not be present in the raw data due to underreporting, incomplete data sources, or unnoticed occurrences. Various validation tests and risk controls are applied throughout the model development process to limit model risk, ensure correct operation, and maintain high-quality output.
Main Areas of Validation and Testing:
description3: By rigorously validating and testing these areas, we ensure the model’s accuracy and reliability.

eventTypesFindings.description: The following plots present the likelihood rates for your industry and size, compared to others.

annualLikelihoodBreakdown.title: Annual Likelihood Breakdown by Initial Vectors, (Above 1%)
annualLikelihoodBreakdown.description: This graph shows what is the baseline annual likelihood for the initial vectors, compared to your company’s likelihood residual rates.

attackVectorsDistribution.title: Distribution of Attack Vectors, within event types
attackVectorsDistribution.description: This graph offers insights into how initial vectors are utilized within different attacker outcomes and goals - the types of events.

companyStructure.title: Company Assets and Structure
description: The second step in the risk modeling process involves the collection of data regarding the company’s assets, structure, and technology stack. This data encompasses the asset count, service providers and your organization's comprehensive IT infrastructure.
Kovrr refines this knowledge by categorizing assets into specific groups, enabling more accurate modeling of potential cyber events aimed at your company.
This holistic data-driven strategy contributes to developing a custom risk profile that aligns with your distinctive technological setup.
Leveraging this information, our model constructs a tailored catalog of realistic cyber events that could impact your organization.
This catalog is not based on generic assumptions, but instead rooted in your specific technology makeup, ensuring the relevance and accuracy of the simulated scenarios.
We incorporate dynamic distributions that factor in frequencies, propagation patterns, and event severity.

This level of detail enables us to simulate cyber incidents based on large-scale insurance claims and policies and other event data from millions of global companies while simultaneously factoring in the unique interplay between your assets and potential vulnerabilities.

technologicalProfile.title: Technological Profile
technologicalProfile.description: The scan of the company uncovered its technological profile, revealing the number of products identified within each technology or security category.

dataBoxes.title: Data Management and Operational Continuity
dataBoxes.description: All these inputs allow us to create realistic events tailored specifically to your company.
dataBoxes.records: Maximum number of data records stored together
dataBoxes.timeToRecover: Average time to recover from outage

eventExamples.title: Event Examples
description: These events are not based on past occurrences but are generated in a bespoke event catalog, tested against the assets and security defenses of the company.

Each event is described using multiple parameters, such as the duration of the interruption, the number of records compromised, the technologies and services impacted, the business impact using the CIA(E), the initial vector and the profile of the actor.
These parameters allow for detailed modeling of how an event unfolds, from the initial attack vector to the likely impact on the organization.

lossImpactScenario.title: Loss Impact Scenario Definitions
lossImpactScenario.description: The six scenarios are mapped to damage types in the following way:

exploitedCves.description: Kovrr employs a well-developed approach to establishing the distribution of exploited technologies in our tailored event catalog. Leveraging our extensive database of vulnerabilities and exploits, we meticulously analyze the risk associated with different technologies. This in-depth analysis enables us to determine the exposure level and potential danger posed by each technology.

ratio.title: Ratio of Exploited CVEs to CVEs, by vendor
ratio.description: This graph presents the ratio between successfully exploited Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures (CVEs) and the total number of CVEs associated with different vendors, focusing on the landscape of the past 12 months.

description: In addition, we meticulously determine the distribution of service providers experiencing outages within the bespoke event catalog through a comprehensive process.

Leveraging our extensive database of global historical outages, we assess the availability of various technologies under different scenarios. This data allows us to accurately model and predict potential disruptions impacting an organization's operations.

graph.title: Global Average Downtime, by provider
graph.description: This graph provides insights into the average number of outages per month and the average duration of downtime per month, considering vendors with the highest scores over the past 12 months.

securityPosture.title: Security Posture
description: Your organization's security posture directly influences the quantification process. By closely examining your company's measures, practices, and technologies to safeguard its digital environment, we can better gauge its resilience against potential cyber threats.
This analysis considers various factors, such as the effectiveness and maturity of your security controls, incident response capabilities, and overall cybersecurity strategy.
The correlation between your security posture and the potential impact of cyber events is essential to accurately financially quantify your organization's cyber risk exposure.

securityControls.title: Security Controls
description: A company's security posture comprises various factors that collectively diminish financial risk and overall exposure.
Some aspects curtail the probability of incidents, while others mitigate their impact.
The following section categorizes your company’s controls implementation into key themes, reflecting the minimum level of implementation for each control.
Each domain contributes to your organization's resilience against cyber threats, aiding you in refining cyber risk management strategies to alleviate financial vulnerabilities.

averageAalDistribution.title: Average Annual Loss Breakdown by Loss Impact Scenarios
averageAalDistribution.description: Breaking down the average annual loss by loss impact scenarios, which reflect six general types of losses that are aligned with standard insurance coverages, highlights the specific drivers behind potential losses in cyber risk.

riskPositionAnalysis.description: Through this simulation, we can pinpoint specific factors that contribute to your risk exposure, including the interplay of various control mechanisms. By examining scenarios such as baseline risk (your company without any controls), current risk (your company's current control situation), and minimal risk (your company with all controls implemented), you will establish a comprehensive perspective on how your security posture influences the likelihood and severity of cyber events.

aal.title: Risk Position Analysis (By average annual loss)
aal.baselineRectangleInfo: This number represents the company's potential average annual loss under a scenario where no security controls are in place.
aal.currentRiskRectangleInfo: This number represents the company's average annual loss at the given time.
aal.lastLineRectangleInfo: This number represents the company's potential average annual loss under a scenario where all security controls are fully implemented.

riskPositionScore.title: Risk Position Score
riskPositionScore.description: This metric evaluates your company's performance in risk reduction by comparing your current risk to the baseline and minimal risk. A higher score indicates more effective risk management and cybersecurity measures, while a lower score suggests room for improvement.

effect.title: How does the security posture affect the likelihood of your company experiencing cyber events?
effect.description: Your company's security controls significantly shape the likelihood of encountering cyber events. Acting as a frontline defense, these controls deter and mitigate threats, reducing the probability of successful attacks. Adequate controls act as barriers against adversaries, enhancing protection. We quantify your security posture's impact on event likelihood by assessing its alignment with industry standards.

finalRiskCalc.title: Final Risk Calculation
description: The fourth step in cyber risk modeling involves running a Monte Carlo simulation to assess the company's risk. This simulation incorporates all the collected data, including threat intelligence, company-specific information, and security posture.
The model considers various scenarios and factors in the inherent uncertainties associated with cyber events by running 10,000 simulation iterations.
To effectively manage cyber risk, it is crucial to understand the potential damages associated with different types of cyber incidents.
Kovrr utilizes a robust cyber risk model, informed by comprehensive threat intelligence data, to calculate the possible damage of cyber events.

controlRecommendations.chapterDescription: Leveraging the Cybersecurity Risk Quantification methodology, this section offers insights into the specific controls that can yield the greatest risk reduction and resilience against potential cyber threats. In this chapter we will review the top 5 recommendations.
